snippet: Thousands of hourly workers took extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with the fear that if they did not go to work , they probably would not be paid.
abstract: Thousands of hourly workers in New York metropolitan area take extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with fear that if they do not go to work, they probably will not be paid; many have little choice, unsure how they will pay for storm-related damages and repairs; low-wage workers have fared worse in the recovery than those at the top of the income scale.

byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and ANDREW MARTIN

lead_paragraph: Thousands of hourly workers took extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with the fear that if they did not go to work , they probably would not be paid.

headline.seo: For Hourly Workers After the Storm, No Work, No Pay
headline.main: For Some After the Storm, No Work Means No Pay
headline.print_headline: For Some After the Storm, No Work Means No Pay
